narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Ethan Addicott  He was fantastic all around
Instructor: Ethan Addicott  Ethan is amazing and has a good grasp of the subject such that he is conveys it wonderfully and has even beginners gaining a lot of insight from his sessions

Instructor: Ethan Addicott  I feel incredibly sorry for the poor souls who have to take this class without Ethan Addicott as the TA. Ethan constantly made himself available to help students and his responses were always promt and helpful. This class had a disconnect between what was covered in class and what was represented in the homework, and Ethan bridged that disconnect in his office hours. Without Ethan's guidance most of the homework assignments would have been unmanageable.
Instructor: Ethan Addicott  Excellent TA. Well versed with the course content, great communicator and was always willing to help.
Instructor: Ethan Addicott  Good input during class, and great effort organizing outside class meetings for review

Instructor: Ethan Addicott  Ethan was so incredibly helpful and generous with his time and energy. He always made sure to plan his office hours so that time was not wasted and make thoughtful priorities for us. In his explanations of complicated mathematical concepts, he would create math "recipes" for us and that was transformative for my learning of the material. THE BEST. Thanks Ethan!
Instructor: Ethan Addicott  Ethan was great--very helpful, made himself available outside of class, put in much effort to help us all understand the material from class.
Instructor: Ethan Addicott  Ethan was a fantastic TA. Always available and really invested in helping students learn. His teaching style was very accessible and easy to follow.

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Extremely useful, but very difficult to cram so much into one semester.

Concepts taught in class and demonstrated in the class videos were not of the same caliber as the homework, which forced students to rely heavily on the TA. In class we were taught how to crawl and then the homework assignments expected you to sprint. I feel like if we could have covered more example problems in class to help build our intuition, rather than the usual 1 or 2 example problems, the intuition would have been there when it was needed for doing the homework.

It would be really helpful to delineate in between concepts more throughout the course lectures. A bit of structure written out in English at the beginning of each class or topic would be really helpful.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Applications to my research
A good primer for catching up to useful applied math concepts. Glad I took the course!
Ethan Addicott

This course teaches relevant mathematical concepts that are incredibly useful for systems thinking applications. The best aspects of the course were the connections the lecturer made between mathematical concepts and their application to the management of natural resources. For example, the concept of limits and how one could apply this thinking to the exhaustion of natural resources over time. The computation of eigenvectors and how they are applied in understanding the stability of a system was an aha- moment for me. Lastly, had I know the full scope of the course beforehand, I would probably have opted not to enroll in the econometrics course at IDE as this course aligned more closely to my academic areas of interest.
Great contextualizing math in a more applied instead of abstract manner
I appreciated learning throughout the course where the mathematical concepts are applied in real life. It was motivating and interesting.

This course provided a really useful reintroduction to concepts I'd learned before but had let lapse since HS/college. Best part of the course was how well it helped me in my other classes where scholarly articles were regularly assigned--I felt I understood the math used in scientific literature better after taking this course.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: There was a huge gap between the level of questions in our homework and the level the material is taught at. It was impossible to do the probem sets without a lot of help from the TA. The R questions were also frustrating. We had a one hour intro to R and were expected to be coding as if we had taken a semester or two of it.

Prof. Fenichel has done a great job of developing a curriculum that helps us catch up to graduate level math in 12 weeks. However, the instruction in class can be improved on, by adding more description of the concepts and possibly offering definitions to concepts in words to aid note making.

The homework assignments. 1) they were at a much higher level of difficulty than what was covering in class, without any build up or prior practice 2) The homeworks (and exams) were often sloppy and riddled with typos. These concepts are hard enough without having to muddle through the instructions and the question prompt's poor grammar.
See above, more structure within the course lectures. More explanations of real world applications throughout.
I would like to see more application of environmental studies problems discussed and used in class. At times, it felt like they were either only explored on PSets or thrown in as an after thought.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Yes. Ethan's discussion sections were incredibly effective.

Book club discussions of the book e -Story of a Number offered great insights into the evolution of widely used mathematical concepts related to the exponent function. TA sessions and R skills workshop were also effective.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: Very important for my overall program and the content aptly caters to that.

I'm focusing on climate and energy policy and given the growing interest in a systems thinking approach to environmental management, I thought it would be useful to understand the mathematical concepts that are widely applied in environmental research.

This course is essential to anyone wishing to conduct any type of quantitative analysis with environmental data, to equip them with necessary understanding of the concepts behind mathematical formulae

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: for my research

I'm focusing on climate and energy policy but from previous work experiences, I was exposed to policy aspects of research on natural capital accounting and valuation as well as research on planetary boundaries. I enrolled in this course because I wanted to gain a better understanding of the underlying of concepts of these highly regarded works.
I wanted to review and practice math
I wanted to increase my overall mathematical and quantitative literacy. I wanted to feel more at ease when problem solving and confronted with complex, dynamic systems.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes!
Yes.
yes

In regards to my response to question 21 - this course definitely made me feel more confident and comfortable with math in my other course this semester and I think it will continue to be valuable as I continue in school and in my career.

Yes. I found this course to be very useful in other courses I was taking this semester--there was a lot of "spillover" of skills/benefits. I think this course gives students a very useful understanding of some fundamental math concepts that many of us haven't used or engaged with in a long time.
I wish there was a better discussion of modeling and how that relates to environmental problems.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: N/A

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: I would highly recommend this course especially if you are interested in ecological modelling or any aspects of resource management. Lastly, had I know the full scope of the course beforehand, I would probably have opted not to enroll in the econometrics course at IDE as this course aligned more closely to my academic areas of interest
Take this course

Take advantage of the resources provided to you--offices hours from both Prof. Fenichel and the TA. Ask a lot of questions. And try to see if you can make connections between what you're learning in AMES and other parts of your coursework. I was surprised to find that the math tools I learned in this course proved useful in just about every other class I was taking.
Only take if you're willing to go in depth with math and take the time to really learn the concepts...and if you need these concepts for your work. Not a supplementary class.
